paper_metadata.title: The Transfer Payment Policy of National Key Ecological Functional Areas (TPEFAP) and its spatial spillovers on poverty alleviation in China

program_information.program_name: Transfer Payment Policy of National Key Ecological Functional Areas (TPEFAP)
program_information.target_population: Rural residents in ecological functional areas

component_a_cash_support.cash_evidence_citation: TPEFAP allocates the subsidies to local governments, which then carry out unified planning and management of the development and construction of key ecological function areas

study_characteristics.outcomes_evidence_citation: For potential channels, rural non-farm employment, rural labor mobility, and agricultural productivity are the key pathways through which the TPEFAP can alleviate poverty both in local and adjacent provinces
study_characteristics.study_design: Synthetic control method (SCM) and dynamic spatial Durbin model
study_characteristics.design_evidence_citation: we utilize panel data covering the key ecological functional areas of China during the period 2011-2018 to evaluate the impact of the TPEFAP on poverty alleviation and also its spatial spillovers by employing the synthetic control method (SCM) and the dynamic spatial Durbin model

evidence_citations.program_name_citation: The Transfer Payment Policy of National Key Ecological Functional Areas (TPEFAP), a well-known ecological compensation (eco-compensation) scheme in China
evidence_citations.country_citation: As the world's largest developing country, China has made a great economic progress in economy owing to reform and opening up
evidence_citations.target_population_citation: TPEFAP was opposed by local farmers who face poverty and difficulties in finding alternative livelihoods during implementation
